author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1709540200}
review:
Strategy & Tactics: Wargame Collection is a collection of three completely free Russian mobile apps that have been dumped on Steam as paid products, deliberately to try scamming gamers into paying money for free mobile apps.  These aren't real PC games... it's a cash grab from greedy mobile devs.

The games are all identical, just reskins of the same turn based strategy game template.  Because the games are identical, they suffer from the same defects which we'll get into... but it's worth summing it up... these mobile apps are just incredibly dumbed down screen tapper strategy games.  Tap your troops, tap the territory to attack... that's basically all you get, but then what do you expect from a mobile app, when this is Steam, for PC games?

From a technical perspective, as a mobile app, this doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

One of the games is only in Russian and doesn't have any English translation that I could find... but don't worry, the games are so shallow, you don't need to be able to read to play them.  And that's a problem in itself. 

There's no option to change the resolution and no useful graphics tweaks.  There's no way to ensure they are running at the native resolution of your display.  There's no guarantee these mobile apps will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

These mobile apps feature mostly static, barely animated 2D images, the kind of thing you expect to see in browser/flash games.  While the artwork itself, while mediocre, might be considered passable, the visual presentation here is negligible, it might as well be a slideshow or a Youtube video.  Pac-Man, Space Invaders and Asteroids had more advanced animation and visuals going on than these mobile apps do.

The controls can't be customised because the mobile apps have such a dumbed down, simplified interface that it's just iPhone screen tapping stuff.  The fact that the interface is this dumbed down might be seen as a problem in itself, however... this is a fairly shallow experience if you're the kind of gamer that likes to play games with deep, rich control schemes and interaction.  You'll get none of that here.

Because these are mobile apps, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the iPhones that the mobile apps were designed for.  These are unfortunate handicaps and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was an afterthought for the iPhone developers who are to blame for this.  These mobile apps are deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for mobile phones forces upon a game.  Once more, mobile devs have made gaming worse for everyone.  I didn't spend thousands on building a gaming rig just so I could pretend it's an iPhone.

These technical defects push these mobile apps below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Strategy & Tactics: Wargame Collection didn't appeal much to the people who own a copy of the mobile apps, either.  It has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the mobile app didn't really capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for completing any mission in any of the three mobile apps, trivial to get, but less than 21 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the mobile app collection.  Hardly a success story, gamers just weren't all that interested in these mobile apps.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this mobile app collection was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the mobile apps.  But this only happened once, around the same time that trading cards were applied to the mobile app collection... so this is just card idlers getting their cards and moving on.  A closer look at the numbers shows the mobile app collection just has a couple of players every week running up one of the mobile apps and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many mobile apps like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

Once more we see greedy mobile devs trying to scam PC gamers. On Steam, this is $10 USD, on app stores, it's free. Mobile devs must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay a premium for a free mobile app just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.  This is unacceptable disrespect for PC gamers.  For comparison, the $10 asking price for this game could get you games like "Disco Elysium", "Deep Rock Galactic" or any number of vastly superior Total War games.  Quality, professionally made games like those are frequently on sale cheaper than this.  

To put it a different way, if you really, really want to play this, go buy Deep Rock Galactic, then play this for free on your iPhone.  See why it's so important not to fall for these mobile app scams?  Buying this would be a complete waste of money. 

Because these can be played free elsewhere, and because of the other defects, it's impossible to recommend them.

Just who do they think we are?

review:
Ich kann dieses Spiele-Bundle empfehlen, allerdings bezieht sich die Empfehlung hauptsÃ¤chlich auf das Sandbox-Spiel im WW2-Setting. Das erste ist historisch angehaucht, wobei die Szenarien in ihrem Ablauf nichts mit dem historischen Verlauf zu tun haben werden. Das letzte ist ein Mittelalter-Setting, das ebenfalls nur kleine Ausschnitte und Szenarien zeigt, wobei die MÃ¶glichkeiten sehr begrenzt bleiben.

Aber zurÃ¼ck zur eigentlichen Empfehlung:
Das Sandbox-Spiel bietet zwei grÃ¶ÃŸere Karten (Europa und Asien), lÃ¤sst zwischen den Nationen der Epoche wÃ¤hlen und ist von seinem Grundprinzip mit dem Brettspiel Risiko vergleichbar, wenngleich es etwas komplexer ist. Gesammelte Produktionspunkte lassen sich in neue Einheiten oder Technologien investieren. Mit deren Hilfe versucht man das Spielfeld im Namen seiner Nation zu erobern. Es gibt unterschiedliche Einheitentypen, die sich beispielsweise in ihrer Bewegungsreichweite unterscheiden. Beachtenswert ist die Anzeige der Kampfbereitschaft einer Einheit, sodass man immerhin Ã¼berlegen muss, ob sich ein ANgriff gerade lohnt oder ob ein Feind aus einem Gegenangriff dann nicht sogar mehr Profit ziehen kann. HauptsÃ¤chlich entscheidet aber eben doch die GrÃ¶ÃŸe der eigenen Armee Ã¼ber Sieg und Niederlage. Was die KomplexitÃ¤t angeht, hat das Spiel offensichtliche Grenzen schnell erreicht. Dadurch ist es aber sehr einsteigerfreundlich und im Mulitplayer durch Kommunikation und BÃ¼ndnisse auch unterhaltsam. Wer alleine spielt, bekommt immerhin eine Auswahl unterschiedlicher Siegbedingungen, die Schwierigkeit und LÃ¤nge des Spiels bestimmen.

review: Solid basic design and art can't take this insufficiently developed set of games far enough to let me recommend them. They play like ported mobile games with an extrtemely grindy attrition-based system, ideally designed to wear down your patience and make you want to buy purchase points for real money. The UI is awkward and everything is very unstable; minimizing a window might lock the screen, and there seems to be a 50/50 chance the game will crash on launch.

author: {'steamid': '76561199214356416', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1709625621}
review:
Simple and easy but quite entertaining. I have played this game for years on the mobile version and is still the same game I love and hate. 

pros: this is the most simple strategy game ever but the main camping and scenarios are challenging. 
-the story is OK but I liked the dialogues and the nice art style for the cut scenes.
-is friendly for beginners in the strategy genre. 
-The sandbox version offers more possibilities and challenges compared to the base game 
- you can run this game on potato 


cons: if you are a paradox player or CIV player this game is probably not for you. Like I mention before this game is super simple and lacks of depths. You'll probably get bored  
-don't even bother to play the medieval game. It lacks content, is even more easy than the two previous games and they got lazy when creating the campaign.
-some levels/ scenarios are almost borderline unfair and is going to take you a couple of tries before figuring out how to to beat them 
-it can become repetitive 


But is a nice game if you are looking for a chill experience

author: {'steamid': '76561198817777981', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 7324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1255, 'last_played': 1661085930}

author: {'steamid': '76561198011250864', 'num_games_owned': 1900, 'num_reviews': 359, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1640551541}
review:
I like these types of games. Risk type, Paradox type games, board game type strategy games.

They dont need to be much, they just need to do what they set out to do well. This game doesnt do that.

For starters, it was designed for phones, so the interface isnt intuitive or pleasant for a PC player. You can also give order to one unit at a time, which can be a huge drag.
Gameplay revolves around attacking tiles and ordering reinforcements, basically. Its fine, but you dont know how combat is calculated and you dont know your unit stats. Without it you dont know if youre forces are good or bad.
There are scenarios with different objectives. They are usually part of campaigns. If you complete these scenarios throughout a campaign you can get upgrades for troops, but these are bare bones.

Its not really worth the time, there is better stuff out there.

2/10

review: An old school type grand strategy game. The game plays like something from the mid 90s. It has an addictive only one more turn feeling. It is easy to pickup and learn. The sound effects are awful. There is 1 song soundtrack that will drive you crazy after several hours. Overall though it's worth adding to your war chest collection if you are a fan of Grand Strategy and the world war 2 era.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009092842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1685305372}
review:
I wouldn't recommend this game. I didn't come into it expecting it to be complex like Gary Grigsby's War In The East etc. But The game doesn't give you any valuable information for combat. You can have a diverse force and give air support but still lose which wouldn't be an issue if I was at least given some sort of display or information if I lose attack power going into wooded areas or forts etc. But no where does it seem to be a thing just RNG bogging you down with no valuable information to plan around it. The Sound Quality is definitely the worst I have ever heard tbh. The music and guns are really loud and poor quality I was forced to turn it down.

Pros: Easy to learn the basics and the UI that is there is also good in terms of understanding what does what. A fun map painter to an extent. good starting army on the sandbox mode

Cons: Doesn't give the player any valuable information. Poor Sound Quality. Despite having two different settings and themes the Medieval and WW2 games play the same and don't offer anything really interesting. The content and quality isn't worth full price and even on sale it's a bit of a stretch

author: {'steamid': '76561198872438177', 'num_games_owned': 48, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 929, 'last_played': 1590199207}
review: This is a board game that is simpler than Axis and Allies 1941.  There are three different games in this package and the Scenerios range in difficulty from easy to very hard (You can't change the difficulty).  There is one very useful chart that is hard to find in the help section called "Unit Stats".  You can find it also on the game's store page and I saved a screenshot as well.  This game can be frustrating but is fun.  This board game is not about graphics but "strategy & tactics".

author: {'steamid': '76561198155969908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 7690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1004, 'last_played': 1707697231}
review: To start off I wanna say this isn't a game of high quality. In fact, I found one of the games in this collection as a mobile game for my phone first (the WW2 Sandbox one) and it was pretty fun, but had all the ads and in-app-purchases that you see with mobile games. I definitely suggest that as a mobile game because it was free and pretty in-depth compared to most strategy games on mobile. On computer, meh. It was incredibly cheap, and even cheaper on sale, which was the main reason I bothered getting it. The deal was pretty good, because this is a 3-pack of games. They all play basically the same, so once you learn one, you learn all of them. As far as strategy games go, it's simple compared to other games like it, and the mechanics become second nature within half an hour to an hour. The tutorials are pretty trashy, and don't cover anything more complicated than basic movement and attacking, which means it's up to you to really explore how combat and movement work. The AI is actually pretty good, but can be predicted and outsmarted with some practice. So why am I recommending this? This may not be a great game, but it's cheap and simple. If you're new to strategy games, or just enjoy casually playing them and don't like diving heavily into grand-strategy games, this is a good choice for you. There's also a mobile version, which I suggest for anyone. If you really like the complicated and in-depth mechanics that you find in games like Hearts of Iron and Victoria 2, though, stay away from this game on PC. There's quite a bit of content, but you'll get bored pretty fast, and personally I would take Hearts of Iron IV any day over these 3 games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198282112410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3501, 'last_played': 1710106711}
review:
[RECENSIONE MODALITA' SANDBOX]
Avete presente RisiKo? Bene, adesso immaginate di poter scegliere singolarmente che classi di divisioni impiegare nella vostra guerra, aggiungete un po' di progressi di ricerca tecnologica ed il gioco Ã¨ fatto.
Questo gioco non Ã¨ limitato a farvi combattere in modo illogico e a farvi mandare a morire milioni di soldati. Infatti, grazie alle vostre direttive, la vostra armata potrÃ  rompere le linee nemiche con combinazioni strategiche pressochÃ© infinite, utilizzando diversi tipi di divisioni combinabili tra terrestri (sia di fanteria che di artiglieria), marittime (sia di superficie che di profonditÃ ) e aeree.
Queste divisioni saranno acquisibili tramite il denaro che raccoglierete dalle vostre province, le quali potranno avere piÃ¹ o meno potere di guadagno.
Ogni divisione ha una salute visibile attraverso una barra colorata al di sotto del simbolo, se la barra Ã¨ verde, la divisione o il corpo d'armata (piÃ¹ divisioni insieme), la sua salute Ã¨ in ottime condizioni, man mano che cala verso il rosso la sua salute diminuisce, questo significa che il vostro "corpo" va ritirato e lasciato a riposare nelle retrovie per qualche turno, in modo tale da risanarlo.
Non dimenticatevi infine di progredire nella ricerca tecnologica militare, la quale vi consentirÃ  di ottenere nuove skills per le vostre divisioni, non vorrete mandarli a combattere la seconda guerra mondiale con fucili "di fango e m***a", vero?
Purtroppo, perÃ², di qualche modifichina necessita anche questo titolo, dato che il livello del volume non Ã¨ modificabile (si puÃ² solamente attivare o disattivare). Inoltre, quando una sola divisione su parecchie Ã¨ mezza morta, non si puÃ² selezionarla singolarmente per farla ripiegare, ed Ã¨ un bel problema di efficienza strategica.

author: {'steamid': '76561198330888468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 507, 'playtime_forever': 4332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1329, 'last_played': 1551417656}
review:
A fun enough game in it's way, but sadly it falls far short of expectations and only seems to reflect the era's of WW II and the  middle ages in the shapes of the units and the maps.

For starters, there really is very little in the way of Strategy or Tactics going on. It is mostly about building big units, as evidenced by France vacating the Maginot Line on turn one of a scenario where my task was supposedly to go thru Belgium. 
And this is only one example of many that make this game so odd. 
Heck, Spain is an active fighting nation, what the heck? Even my eight year old grand-daughter scoffed at how unrealistic it was. 
In one scenario, my German fleet blocked the channel unopposed, because every nation seems to have equal (and impressive) shipyards!
It doesn't help that when you have an an ally you can't go on their land, meaning the British are unable to support France at all on land. 
I can think of numerous simple ways it could have been improved without breaking a sweat, and the makers of this game should have too.
To make matters worse, there appears to be no community left for it, which doesn't help much at all.
Cannot recommend unless you find it offered for free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084633164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1573346956}
review:
This is basically Risk. A simple strategy game, though the different types of units add a nice layer of complexity without going too crazy. The options are quite straightforward: attack-move, support, airstrike, relocate troops... The maps and scenarios I tried were interesting.

The user interface is simple, even minimalistic, and easy to grasp. As others have said, it is also very clanky. You can't use the scroll button or ASDW keys, and have to navigate through the minimap, which gets annoying fast. There is also no help or info menu besides 2 pages of obscure infographics. 

All in all, recommend, but I got it on sale. I'll probably be playing the game very occasionally so the price was right for me.

review: An embarrassingly poor game. The graphics are very outdated. The interface is clunky in the extreme - you cannot even scroll the map, you have to click on the minimap constantly. There is no depth to it. Uninstalled.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966511621', 'num_games_owned': 1216, 'num_reviews': 609, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1541952601}
review: This is a pretty bad strategy game that fails to explain its mechanics and is ridiculously limited in scope. The UI doesn't scale well in 4K and is pretty clumsy overall. There's absolutely no reason to play this with games like Hearts of Iron around.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107590592', 'num_games_owned': 6, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1539233583}
review: Dear Devs, thank you for creating a challenging WW2 wargame with fine touches. Good single player AI cpu opponent. Great free missions. Both war in Europe, and battles in Pacific theater. Air & sea units that work well. All in all a great strategy game. Great work. I look for your next polished game. WOULD be interested in smaller scale battles over few KM terrain, missions in main theaters Western Front, D-Day /Battle of the Bulge, Eastern Front, Pacific Islands. Thanks! :'D

author: {'steamid': '76561198276129712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1538824910}
review: Its the best game I ever played about WW2. However, I stopped playing it as I realized the Soviet Union (USSR) always manages to afford bombers and create a large army at the first few turns, in both the European and the Asian theater, making it very difficult to complete objectives that include this country. Its unfair and stressful to play the game and see all this red already conquer a third of the continent, with a ridiculously large army and air force.

author: {'steamid': '76561198863616847', 'num_games_owned': 5, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1538715017}
review: I was looking for a more complex strategy game to play and thought I'd try this one. The big problem I noticed is that with the tutorials, it still takes a lot of time to fully learn how the game works. The gameplay and strategy work well, but I hate how allies block areas that you perhaps need to go through (for missions). This is one of the biggest issues for me, but the rest is pretty fun. As a recomendation, I'd love it if there were diplomacy options, as in ways to switch sides,more neutrality or peace between other nations, or a way to maybe trade resources/provinces. I'm sure there are more problems that could come from this, but I'd love a aspect that doesn't completely scream war. Aside from this, the game is very fun and I enjoy conquering enemy forces over and over. Keep up the good work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198441820163', 'num_games_owned': 26, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1554664029}

review: This game is pretty cool. The cut scenes dialogue between officers is very interesting and so are their campaigns... All it's missing us more 2+ player maps and single player missions (I would like to see a bigger focus in the Pacific) but other then that this game is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198853791431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1535565662}
review: Firstly, amazing job. Secondly, the a.i is pretty dumb at times, like I had one game as France where Denmark conquered berlin., But it's not often. Lastly, it would be cool if countries could join alliances, and if everyone didn't just immediately start out at war. Great game, very fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982531514', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1565496059}
review:
I tried to enjoy this strategic war game but it falls very short of being acceptably fun. Although I purchased the game for about $3 on sale I still feel it was a waste of my time and little satisfaction was received. If you're looking for a Panzer General type game this is far from it. No mouse scrolling, poor implementation of scenarios and campaigns that made me feel it was unfullfilling. Do you know what I mean? You finish a scenario and are delighted and satified that you had fun and that it was worth your time; not with this game!
You would probably be better off playing checkers as it has about as much depth as this game. Decent graphics and what looks like lots of replayability is how this looks on the surface but then after sinking some time into it you realize it was just poorly conceived and probably just optized for playing on mobile phones.
My advice; don't pay over $2, get it on sale for 75% to 90% off otherwise you are wasting your money.

In Medieval Wars: Strategy & Tactics;
Drei historische Kampagnen, die Heere Englands, Frankreichs und der KreuzzÃ¼gler. Ziehe in die Schlacht zu zeiten des 9. bis zum 15. Jahrhundert. Dank den Szenario basierten Karten kannst du fÃ¼r die Rus an den Schlachten teilnehmen, unter dem Banner Karls des GroÃŸen die Sarazenen aufhalten und den Aufstand der Hussiten entfachen. Dazu kommen noch vier verschiedene historische Szenarien mit 21 Arten von Truppen.
Auch dieses Spiel nutzt das Gameplay der beiden anderen, hat aber eine deutlich schÃ¶nere Karte.

Allgemeine Empfehlung fÃ¼r Neulinge. PersÃ¶nliche Meinung Negativ.

Strategy & Tactics: Wargame Collection
You get three games here via a start window.
Released as a set 2016. Totally overhauled review.
Below is a brief description of the three titles.

Strategy & Tactics: WW II;
Take command of German, Soviet or Allied armies and lead your men to victory in three challenging story-based campaigns. Dozens of combat mode maps and seven historical scenario maps.
Both players who like to play for hours on giant maps, as well as lovers of short conflicts come in the scenario-based single player battles fully at their expense.

WW2: Sandbox. Strategy & Tactics;
28 countries available for election.
You can maintain the historic political alliances and defeat Germany as commander of the USSR army along with the Western powers, or you can disable the alliances and celebrate your victory on the rubble of London.
Random events such as guerilla movements, land operations, voluntary retreats, etc. increase the replay value. Europe map with over 500 areas and
39 playable countries.

These two games use the same interface and are the same as the sun. You play on a crumpled large-format map that is divided into many areas and regions and has also been heavily colored. This is not exactly nice but very well visible and easy to understand. Especially for newcomers who do not want to do a course to understand what units they have, the pictures are very simple. The gameplay is just as simple gestalltet. I could complain now because everything is "so" primitive designed, but I do not. Anyone who has recorded once will notice that this is quite beneficial for those who just want to play it in between times or can.

In Medieval Wars: Strategy & Tactics;
Three historic campaigns, the armies of England, France and the crusaders. Go to battle in the 9th to 15th century. Thanks to the scenario-based maps, you can take part in the battles for the Rus, stop the Saracens under the banner of Charlemagne, and unleash the Hussite rebellion. There are also four different historical scenarios with 21 types of troops.
Also this game uses the gameplay of the other two, but has a much nicer card.

General recommendation for newcomers. Personal opinion Negative.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050016554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1530204371}
review:
Les mÃ©canismes sont Ã  peine plus compliquÃ©s que ceux du Risk. Difficile de trouver cela intÃ©ressant alors que tant d'autres jeux offrent plus de possibilitÃ©s tactiques et stratÃ©giques. Que ce ne soit pas beau et que la musique soit pÃ©nible, on s'en moque un peu pour ce genre de titre mais Ã§a n'aide pas Ã  s'accrocher.

C'est peut-Ãªtre sympa en multi, moi je joue en solo et je ne me suis pas amusÃ©.

Les scÃ©narios que j'ai jouÃ©s Ã©taient pour la plupart trÃ©s dÃ©sÃ©quilibrÃ©s quantitativement, qualitativement et  territorialement. Avec en plus une limite de tour qui ne laisse pas vraiment le temps de s'organiser. Sachant qu'une pile encerclÃ©e (y compris par des alliÃ©es vu que chaque rÃ©gion ne peut recevoir que 12 unitÃ©s) va presqu'Ã  coup sur se rendre, certains scÃ©narios mÃ©diÃ©vaux me paraissent totalement hors de ma portÃ©e vu l'infÃ©rioritÃ© numÃ©rique et la distance aux objectifs de dÃ©part. C'est moins flagrant pour la partie WWII, mais ma principale reflexion sur ce jeu consistait Ã  prÃ©voir des trous dans mes lignes. Ca ne m'Ã©clate pas.

Je ne suis pas un cador, c'est sur, mais quand je vois que moins de 2% des joueurs ont les succÃ¨s au-delÃ  de la premiÃ¨re campagne, je me sens moins seul Ã  ne pas apprÃ©cier Strategy&Tactics: Wargame Collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145270074', 'num_games_owned': 41, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1528910063}
review: I'm not a hardcore gamer. At the beginnining it seems like too much info to keep track of. however if you follow the tutorial and stick with it, and experiment with the balance between army and commerce, you will enjoy the game immensly. Like my favorite games, the basics are easy, but the overall challenge is huge. A lot of time and care put into this one. For the price I would highly recommend it. It allows you to stop, think, then proceed. And it doesn't bury you with too much information, and when the enemy attacks it just shows you the results, you don't have to sit through some boring junk.

review:
First, to the people who complain that the game is in another language (i.e., Russian), look at your screen and try clicking on the button in the upper right hand corner - this is the language selection button.

However, changing the language has been the highlight of owning this game. In the tutorial none of the unit controls work which is just as well since you are not really being taught about how to play the game.

Refund requested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147439638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1547606583}
review:
Imagine playing a game of Risk for the very first time, with a friend who fails to explain all of the rules to you -- and then proceeds to cheat all through the game. Just imagine that for a moment.

Now you have an idea of what these games are like, except that in Risk you'd have the satisfaction afterwards of kicking your friend in the jimmie for being a jackwad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198161296700', 'num_games_owned': 11, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 94, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1526156598}
review:
When it comes down to what matters though, the strategy, Strategy and Tactics is decent in theory but middling in execution. Players can recruit a variety of units like soldiers, tanks, and bombers and call them in when enough time has passed and enough cash has been saved. They can also split units apart and relocate them to strongholds and other conquered areas of the map for a tactical advantage. Players can even spend time between missions researching scientific military enhancements. 

However, in practice these admittedly intriguing ideas fail to make up for the vague confusion that plagues most battles. Itâ€™s hard to get a grasp on just how much one can do in a single turn which is compounded by slightly unresponsive controls. More problematic though is the lack of information given about a battle between any two units. While victories never feel random at times it is hard to tell why one unit is stronger than another or if strategies like having one unit support another are actually working. Intel like that is pretty important for progressing through a strategy game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198804633383', 'num_games_owned': 15, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1523369821}
review: This game surprised me. I picked it up on a Steam sale thinking how wrong can I go for a couple of bucks. I'm used to playing Axis and Allies, both the Milton Bradley board games as well as the old Nova Games, which was the best...I also play the triplea version, which is excellent. This game is much more in line with the Milton Bradley games. A relatively simple game, simple mechanics. That being said, there are some very nice features that I enjoy. You can plot out moves in a step by step fashion. Moving infantry to take the first territory, then "relocating" mech units into the newly taken territory, and then launching an attack with them into the next. I don't see myself playing this game for hours on end straight but I do expect I will come back to it again and again. Games are quick and make you think because your time and resources are limited.

review:
Difficile de recommander ce jeu.

Les graphismes sont datÃ©s. Beaucoup trop. (Je n'ai pas fait attention Ã  la date de sortie)
L'ambiance sonore...n'en parlons pas, j'en ai mal aux oreilles et j'ai coupÃ© le son du jeu aprÃ¨s 15 mins.
Le jeu est trÃ¨s statique et je n'arrive pas y accrocher. 20 minutes ont suffit au jeu pour me dÃ©courager. Trop rigide, des "bip bip" sonores dans tout les sens. Pas intuitif, non vraiment j'ai beaucoup mal avec ce jeu.
Pour le cotÃ© historique...oui j'imagine que c'est un peu prÃ©sent.

Sinon Ã§a reste des jeux trÃ¨s simple, (2 sont en fait le mÃªme sauf que un est en russe uniquement et l'autre un genre de version mÃ©dievale du genre.

Comme dit dans un autre commentaire, attendez Heart of the Iron ou prenez un des prÃ©cÃ©dents. Ã§a vaudra mieux son prix que ce jeu ci.

N'oublions pas que ce n'est que mon avis. pour 9â‚¬, Ã§a peux plaire Ã  certains mais il ne faut pas trop en demander dans ce cas.

A+

author: {'steamid': '76561198166881389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1357, 'last_played': 1515463531}
review: Solid basic design and art can't take this insufficiently developed set of games far enough to let me recommend them. They play like ported mobile games with an extrtemely grindy attrition-based system, ideally designed to wear down your patience and make you want to buy purchase points for real money. The UI is awkward and everything is very unstable; minimizing a window might lock the screen, and there seems to be a 50/50 chance the game will crash on launch.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995949116', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1612, 'last_played': 1514290944}
review:
These are simple, easily accessible but still entertaining games that can provide a quick fix of Risk-style gaming in between your Civilization of Crusader Kings campaigning

They are a good way to introduce someone to PC war gaming who may be putoff by the perceived complexity of many main stream strategy titles or who like me was traumatized when a friend started me off with Europa Universalis

author: {'steamid': '76561198113455411', 'num_games_owned': 6008, 'num_reviews': 157, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1513247148}
review:
[h1]Info zu Strategy & Tactics: Wargame Collection von HeroCraft[/h1]
Leider nicht das erste neugierige Spiel dieser Firma. Mit diversen Nutzerdaten telefoniert dieser Titel gleich 2 Adressen ohne Wissen des Spielers ab und fÃ¼llt die hauseigene Datenbank.

[h1]Aufgerufen werden:[/h1]
[list]
[*] gamestats.herocraft.com
[*] statistics.herocraft.com
[/list]

Gesendet werden unter anderem die verwendete Windowsversion, Spracheinstellungen, Programmlaufzeit des Spielers, sowie eine diverse Anzahl "leerer" Parameter (referer, userid usw.)

Block beider Adressen wird vor Spielstart empfohlen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042465052', 'num_games_owned': 1687, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1548135953}
review: This is more of a game to learn the strategy genre if a person is really interested in it. There are a lot more games that have more to offer than this one but not to take anything away from these 3 titles in one package. It does have in-depth tutorials that help people that haven't been exposed to them learn and not get frustrated because the tutorials are kicking your backside. This one actually helps you win while learning them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009263731', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1536113776}
review:
WWII Sandbox is the only one I liked. No turns limitation, huge map with zoom in/out, lots of units and yet there are specific missions you can accomplish although you can continue conquering other countries in free mode after that (actually whole gameplay feels like free mode anyways, which is good). Took me like 2 hours to play one tough round to accomplish mission and... I did it and am very proud of that as it was hard and lots of thinking involved! Would do that again, really, highly recommended!

Btw learning curve is not steep, without any previous grand strategies experience, you can understand how it all works in 10 minutes by following basic and advanced tutorials and starting your first scenario.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025641760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 2042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1964, 'last_played': 1703985577}
review:
If you have ever played Axis and Allies or Risk its pretty similar and just as fun. 

Cons: Big time crash issue. Once large armies get built up the game seems to crash at least once every turn.
Pro: The game auto saves after every action you take during each turn  so when it crashes you just have the inconvience of restarting from your last action point.

I am giving a yes based on the hopes that the crash issue gets fixed. If it didnt auto save so often it would be a definite no due to starting over all the time with the crashes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047344005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1508816730}
review:
This game would be much better to play if its strict limited number of moves were removed. Once the limit number of turms has occurred the entire campaign is over. 

The strict limited number of moves to win/lose is completely obsurd and kills all motivation to play this otherwise fun game. For example, the first "battle" is actually a campaign and requires the taking of Jerusalem (starting just south of what is Istanbul, Turkey today. The basic timing problem is your (Crusader forces) most forward unit is not only weakest but it takes every single move allowed just to get there. That means not only does that one unit have to survive but it has to conquer 14 provinces inbetween without fail and without any reinforcements. Until that time limit is removed I cannot recommend the game. Only calvary can move "two spaces" per turn but getting a strong enough calvary force takes more than half the game which negates the "two province" move advantage. I keep trying and getting better at it. I think I am beginning to enjoy it, it certainly is challenging.  

More turns (2x) per campaign, pretty please.

Notes: the use of the word "infidel" is an Islamic term used to describe non-Muslims but the narrative in the game uses it when referencing either side. Christianity described Muslims as "unbelievers" which has the same meaning. 

Almost Last: I have only pruchased this for the Crusades, I have not played or evaluated the other two modern conflicts.

Historical: The first (unorganized) Crusade was in 1091 AD. From 650 AD to that time Islam had conquered a significant portion of Christiandom, all of north Africa, Spain and Portugal, and Southern France and all the way to the bounders ancient India which at that time included modern day Pakistan. So, for 441 years, until 1091 all battles and campaigns were strictly defensive ones for Christianity. What surprises me, in this game, is the extend of the fighting between the various caliphates. My interest has peak in that respect, I need to research that.

Overall, considering what you pay for a movie ticket these days, this game is worth what it costs. I hopr to see a few improvements, like expanded turns, open ended campaigns, health level on each unit.

Thank you :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198317019209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1487591467}
review: The three games are similar to each other with slight differences, the differences aren't anything major, mainly just the games setting, two of the games are set in World war two, while the third game takes it back old school to the days of Knights and kings.. Great stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129974730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1487590791}
review: A really fun, casual strategy game that's worth picking up. You'll find yourself pulling off classic strategic maneuvers with armies and it's really rewarding when they work. Don't pick this up expecting anything realistic, the game is obviously designed to be a fun experience irrelevent of historical accuracy. As a fan of WWII history and strategy, I still enjoyed this game for what it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045440825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1525880242}
review: This game surprised me.  I picked it up on a Steam sale thinking how wrong can I go for a couple of bucks.  Now being blunt, it does not have spectacular graphics, the sound track is mediocre and repeats a lot and initial impressions on the game play seemed as simple as checkers.  Then I started getting into a couple of scenarios.  Yes, the move set is simple but it quickly became apparent every aspect of the moves was ingeniously important.  The order of the moves, which units should move before others, playing a couple of moves and executing them vs. moving many units before executing them, did you remember to block an escape route for the enemy before attacking but did that now make you too weak to succeed in the attack or leave you a easy counter attack victim and more.  I don't see myself playing this game for hours on end straight but I do expect I will come back to it again and again.  Games are quick and make you think because your time and resources are limited.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012992721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1593298978}
review: A totally unexpected gem. It's cheap and doesn't really look like much at first. How many times have we seen the map of Europe with little tanks and infantrymen? When you play, though, it's deep and immersive. It definitely has that "just one more turn" thing that great turn-based games have. It simplifies most of the elements, but it doesn't really dumb them down too much. It's not Hearts of Iron but it actually is more fun. The added bonus here is that you get three games for the price. I haven't played the medieval game yet but I believe that it's going to be fun as well. Very nice job by the devs at Herocraft.  Last thought - game is totally stable - so far no crashes or glitches at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091536411', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1644956178}
review:
I first played the app of the Sandbox Mode. I enjoyed it very much but there was too much "Pay to Enjoy" content, so I eventually stopped playing it completely.

Today, I found a game that was on sale and checked it out. I was shocked to find out it was the exact same game I played on mobile and that it included 2 games with a sandbox mode! I immediately checked to see if it had in-game purchases. Nope? Purchased! Immediately spent 3.5 hours playing it.

I completely recommend this game if you like strategy, but you have to be careful what you do. If you expand too fast then you will spread your armies thin which in turn can prove both benefitial and disasterous. Play your hand well, and you might just be able to conquer the whole map!

[b]NOTE[/b]
This review is solely based on app and PC version of Sandbox Mode! I have not tried either of the campaigns yet!
I will change my review when I give them both a shot! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198152760885', 'num_games_owned': 17519, 'num_reviews': 481, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1645713136}
review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Developed and published by HeroCraft, Strategy & Tactics: Wargame Collection is just as its name suggests, a collection of three wargames focusing mainly on European warfare during the Middle Ages and World War Two. I was surprised to find out that this is in fact a PC port of games developed for mobile platforms initially. They are very well polished for a Steam debut.
 
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Strategy & Tactics: Wargame Collection has plenty of replay value considering we have three distinct open-ended campaigns. Medieval Wars: Strategy & Tactics, of course sets itself apart from the other two, Strategy & Tactics: WWII (story-based) or WW2: Sandbox, which as the name implies offers more freedom to players, who can choose from 28 nations to steer through the war. All three are anything but static, since the AI can give you an enticing challenge should you select a higher tier difficulty setting. The games contain multiplayer options in the form of hotseat mode but I found the playerbase to be severely lacking and I stuck to fighting the AI, most of the time. I was never bored but then again, grand strategy is an aquired taste.

While the gameâ€™s graphics arenâ€™t really something to brag about, they serve their purpose fair enough as this is the standard interface to this type of strategy. Youâ€™re supposed to stare at a map and plan ahead. The 2D unit icons have sufficient diversity and the hundreds of regions presented to us, seem accurate as far as I can tell from my hefty experience with such games.
 
It is almost a golden rule for strategy games of any given subgenre, to have a very good musical score and this title doesnâ€™t fail to impress either. The songs and themes are fitting well within the game modes and settings. 
 
[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Balanced difficulty scale and eloquent tutorial
+ Pleasant soundtrack
+ Steam Trading Cards
 
[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Many gameplay and interface similarities between the three scenarios
- No Steam Achievements
 
[h1]Result / Final thoughts[/h1]
As I become more mature from an intellectual perspective I began to try out and actually enjoy grand strategy games. This subgenre relinquishes any form of eye-candy in the name of pure strategic thinking. Consider yourself in a war room, surrounded by maps and constant reports about troop placement. Would it be considered fun by you? If the answer is â€œnoâ€, you should still give it a chance. Use the tutorial and keep an open mind about it all. Such strategies do contain a steep learning curve, but once you get the hang of it, Iâ€™m certain that the experience shall be a breath of fresh air. Stop being just a follower of orders and issue them yourself!
 
[b]Rating 8/10[/b]
 
[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/elitegives]Elite Giveaways[/url], check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA titles.[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198114186986', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1491121345}
review:
Strategy & tactics: War game collection is for those who want to venture out into the free World of imaginative tactical strategy game playing World with a time machine. For this game has three parts each unfolding a new type of game play, while two of them venturing into the (WWII) era while the third one in to the medieval era. But make no mistake this a TBS gamers delight. The game encircles primarily around Europe in a grand strategy sort of game play,  apart from any major ideological drawbacks.

Imagine a World where you are either the allies namely U.S.A. , Britain,  France or the axis namely the Japan, Germany or Italy.Now youre given resources and military supplies based on the amount of resources you have and have been ordered to conquer different parts of the World.(but in a fun sort of way). This game offers exactly that in the sandbox mode. One thing worth mentioning here is that the war is strictly fought over Europe and some parts of Japan. There are key provinces which you must control to win the game. Each province offers some resources (generally 1 crate/gold coin). There are a few provinces in which and in only them can you call your reinforcements. one complaint here is that because of the enourmity of the sandbox mode .Its hard to keep track of all the troops or troop movements in one turn.So it is advised you play the tutorial or the second part of the game first.

This part is the campaign mode, where you play as any of the (WWII) powers and conquer your enemies provinces one by one.Theres also a bit of cinematics to this part of the game, as you generally see the WWII characters come to life on your screen.Here it is worth mentioning that the music is different for different versions of the base game.How ever they are all superb.

The music in the third version of the game takes our adventure to the medieval era, where the rules are a bit different. The WWII is nonexistent.Here instead of crates of supplies you gain coins. These coins you use to buy gold from special provinces marked with a small camp sign. how ever it is worth mentioning here that, the amount of resources you generate each turn is limited and is proprtional to the amount of area you control of the map.

The game play overall is smooth and and its a very fun game for strategy and tactical game fans. You get to call in all the units of each era in each era you play in a time specific manner. There are special citadel structure on the map,  on special provinces that gives defensive bonuses. In each missions depending on the era you can earn bouses like research points , that unlocks new advantages in millitary or industry. Or medals which grant bonuses. but to achieve these you must fionish the game in a limited number of turns. It is also noteworthy that in each game you start off with a limited amount of land. The game has many pros and relatively no cons, but to mention a few.

PROS

+ The game has three different versions in one complete game.
+ The price for this three games are of that of one
+ Sound strategy sanse and tactical sense implemented in this game
+ Tons of units from each era present in the game namely horseman,longbow man,tanks,aircrafts,motorized vehicles to
   name a few
+ Sound music in all three versions of the game
+ Self explanatory tutorials which are fun
+ Fun tech tree specially in campaign mode

CONS

_The sand box mode needs to be gotten used to, else theres a feeling of nausea with every turn end

All in all its a 7/10 game,owing to its low price tag. The game is a must have for a strategy game fan who likes turn based gameplay and tactics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038558930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1620, 'last_played': 1491801259}
review:
Ok, here's my take on the game. I'm used to playing Axis and Allies, both the Milton Bradley board games as well as the old Nova Games, which was the best...I also play the triplea version, which is excellent. This game is much more in line with the Milton Bradley games. A relatively simple game, simple mechanics. That being said, there are some very nice features that I enjoy. You can plot out moves in a step by step fashion. Moving infantry to take the first territory, then "relocating" mech units into the newly taken territory, and then launching an attack with them into the next. You are not required to to plan out every move for all your troops, they can be executed one at a time. This is definately a "beer and pretzels" kind of game. 
There are, of course, things that I feel need to be addressed to make this a truly awesome game. And I do believe the potential is there. One of the issues that I saw in other reviews was that there is no diplomacy. Since this game is based on WWII, the sides are pretty much determined. Don't let that stop you from buying this game. However, it is true that you are unable to move your troops through an allies territory. This is quite problematic. England is pretty much handicapped until Germany makes the mistake of taking a coastal province. As long as you don't do that, and there is no compelling reason to do so, you've effectively blocked any invasion from that front. As Germany, you are completely unable to send troops to aid Italy. English and French navies will never combine. Spain is pretty much on its own. Think of it as a first come, first serve kind of war. If I get there before my allies, they are going to have to figure out another way around, and if they get there first...oh well. This is the one thing that I feel needs to be addressed. The war was Axis and Allies...oh, and Russia. Axis and Allies and Russia. Not Germany, an independant state that promised not to attack Italy, Italy, an independant state that promised not to attack Germany, France, an independant state that promised not to attack England, England, an independant state, Romania...etc. Once that gets fixed, I would definately recommend this game. As is, it's enjoyable, just could be better...

author: {'steamid': '76561198082995144', 'num_games_owned': 21951, 'num_reviews': 261, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1461713495}
review:
Three games in one... YES please, three good games in one... YOU rock, Strategy and Tactics isn't just a single amazing Strategy game it's three of them.  WOW, you can't top that value three top notch super fun strategy games for a low price... Where do I sign up???   You already know the answer it's this games store page.  

The three games are similar to each other with slight differences, the differences aren't anything major, mainly just the games setting, two of the games are set in World war two, while the third game takes it back old school to the days of Knights and kings..  Great stuff. 

[h1]Strategy and Tactics World War 2,[/h1] allows you to play as one of three super powers from the second world war, the Axis, The allies, and the USSR.  The game has loads of skirmish mode maps, and 7 historical scenario based maps.  The game also has a multiplayer mode which I admittedly didn't play, although the single player game was enough to keep me learning and burning..  Lots of fun to play, dominate your enemies and bring them to their knees.  

[h1]Strategy and Tactics WW 2 Sandbox[/h1] is almost the same as the non sandbox game, with the difference being it's more open and accessible, you can pick one of 39 countries to pick from, a great mode to kick back and let your old school strategy game playing flag fly.  destroy the world through force or through.... FORCE, bend all he countries to your own personal will..  Are you going to go all out crazy and outlaw crazy mustaches, or maybe you'll ban men from wearing Skirts.. (that won't go over too well in Scotland)  Whatever you choose, this is your option if you want a more open experience that is far more open ended.

[h1]Strategy and Tactics Medieval [/h1]....  I'm sure you heard the expression, I'm about to go Medieval up in this piece... well this game is just that.  Go back to a point in time when king's sat on their iron thrones, knights patrolled the country sides in search of maidens to rescue and King Arthur pulled the magical sword from the stone..  (Ok I lied about the King Arthur part... I'm a bad boy)  What Medieval does have is 3 historical campaigns, 4 historical scenarios, more skirmish maps than you can shake a stick at.  

Three games in one, pick your poison and get ready to rumble because in this game you'll be rumbling and bumbling for sure.

[h1] Pro's[/h1] 

3 games in 1 neat package
Awesome tutorials, let you know just how to crush you enemies
Fun gameplay 
AI that doesn't suck

[h1] Con's[/h1]

You get 3 games, but they all have very similar gameplay
Slightly repetitive game play
pretty bad User Interface 
Could have used a bit more complexity in non combat aspects

[h1] Recommendation[/h1]

Well Strategy and Tactics won't be the game of the year, what it will do is offer you a chance to play a fun historical strategy game that has just the right difficulty to allow the gamer to feel like the boss, but keeping you on your toes at the same time.   I absolutely found the game to be thoroughly enjoyable and well worth the purchase point.  The few negatives the game has are overshadowed by the positives, and really leave the gamer enthralled by a visceral experience that can keep you entertained for hours on end.  Strategy fans should buy this immediately, it's a quality title, with decent Ai, and fast paced game-play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079593606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1687, 'last_played': 1462037323}
review:
Strategy & Tactics ist ein simples, aber dennoch fordendes Spiel.

+ Einfaches Spielprinzip (in etwa wie Risiko)
+ Technologie-Baum
+ Szenario (2. Weltkrieg und Mittelalter)
+ gut aufeinander abgestimmte Einheiten (nicht zu viele, nicht zu wenige, und ausgewogen)
+ ideal fÃ¼r zwischendurch
+ viele Nationen

- kein Sandbox-Modus fÃ¼r Mittelalter-Spiel
- keine Diplomatie 
- Sound kann teilweise nerven

Ich persÃ¶nlich wÃ¼rde mich auf Updates freuen (Sandbox fÃ¼r Mittelalter? Pazifik-Map? Diplomatie?)
FÃ¼r Strategiespieler, die das Szenario mÃ¶gen und Risiko-Fans auf jeden Fall einen Blick wert!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970367582', 'num_games_owned': 9159, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1486383418}
review:
Yet another example of trash on steam, i had hopes that this was Risk with alittle bit of depth, its neither

- Its a mobile port
- Tutorial that fails on the most basic level
- No sound sliders
- Unit resolutions are horrible
- Feels more like a puzzle than a wargame, you have to attack in an exact order to accomplish bonus goals
- No diplomacy (Devs have said they will add this, i don't see how it can save this game tho)

This has no place on steam, and should have remained a mobile game

author: {'steamid': '76561197991516314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1461785659}
review:
A really fun, casual strategy game that's worth picking up. 

Everything's nice from animations to sound effects, and its also great how far you could go with the simplicity of the game.

You'll find yourself pulling off classic strategic maneuvers with armies and it's really rewarding when they work.

A properly placed attack can encircle an army and wipe it out. 

However, there are some cons about the game design itself. The UI is very annoying to use, the click-click option for moving armies is really a pain to use. I suggest they'd exclusivley use a click-and-drag instead so nothing gets mixed up in your commands.

Don't pick this up expecting anything realistic, the game is obviously designed to be a fun experience irrelevent of historical accuracy. As a fan of WWII history and strategy, I still enjoyed this game for what it is.

Thumbs up for the developers and I hope we see some updates soon.

P.S. Check my guide on this title; it's very helpful for newcomers/casual strategy players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079623191', 'num_games_owned': 1726, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1461515005}
review: The game itself isn't bad, it's everything that makes the game thats bad. In this game you can pick from a WW2 style or medival style board game type. I played the WW2 sandbox and you would think that would be awsome. But there is no telling what is going on. In the game I played recently I was Spain. I thought I would have a little bit of diplomacy, nothing major but something like "Start a war" or "Peace" but no, The game chooses your side. If you are Spain you are Axis, flanked by the French, the Americans and Protugal (Sorry for the misspelling) and whats worse is that there is no way around this. THere is no "I want peace" button. You are at war against everyone thats an ally. This makes it terribly confusing because before that happened, I thought I was my own country, not on a set team. Whats the money? Supply. Each turn and depending on how many cities you have, you get Supply. This is used to purchase troops and develop research. Not bad, fairly simplistic but not bad. Except when you factor in that all the stuff that is worth anything at all is 100+ supply. When you purchase a unit, depending on how expensive it is, they have a strength number. If it is at a twelve, it is a full army. There is also a health system in the game where if you lose all your health, the units die. There is naval and air but those are the same things unless bombing with aircraft or ships which is by a slider. Thats it. The game's idea isn't bad at all. I like Risk and I love board games. But this game does it all wrong with AI that I swear cheats because as Spain, I was spending money trying to scrounge up troops while the US has armies of 12 all over the place as well as the French did as well at least five turns in. The game also doesn't teach you everything in the game. I had a difficult time figuring out what goes with what. I say, stay away.

review: First impressions are "when exactly did Norway have more troops then the Red Army in 1944?".  Either this is intended to play like an Advanced Wars like puzzle game where there is only one way to figure out the given scenarios puzzle and win, or simply needs badly re-balanced.   Either way not much of a wargame sim.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141401549', 'num_games_owned': 2944, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1461473612}
review:
[quote]A bang for the buck for turn-based, strategy fans as this collection features three games in one buy![/quote] 

[h1][u][b]Game Overview[/b][/u][/h1]

[b]Strategy & Tactics - Wargame Collection[/b] is a package of three turn-based strategic games namely "Strategy & Tactics: World War II", "Strategy & Tactics: World War II Sandbox", and "Strategy & Tactics: Medieval Wars".

In [b]Strategy & Tactics: World War II[/b], you can play as one of the three forces prominent during the World War II which are the "Axis Powers", the "Soviet Union" (USSR), and the "Allied Forces" in each of their respective campaigns.
The skirmish mode features tons of maps for you to choose as well as seven (7) scenario-based maps. It also has a hot-seat mode available for you to play 1v1 with either an AI opponent or with your friend.

The gameplay in [b]Strategy & Tactics: World War II - Sandbox[/b] is quite similar with "Strategy & Tactics: World War II", however it showcases a rather single-player style skirmish with AI. 
In this one, you can pick on the main objective for you to priotize in order to win the game, which of the 39 countries you are going to play as, and the alliance settings for the session.

[b]Medieval Wars: Strategy & Tactics[/b] also borrows the game mechanics from the first two games in the pack, but is executed with a different period as it is set on the medieval ages. 
Campaign mode has three (3) armies for you to play as which are the "English Armies" (England), the "French Troops" (France), and the "Crusader Forces". It also has skirmish, hotseat and scenario mode that is similar of the first two games.

All in all, the games seems to focus on a more combat-oriented strategy rather than a combined gameplay with diplomatic aspects.

[h1][u][b]The Pros[/b][/u][/h1]

[list]

    [*][b]Detailed Tutorial[/b] - Having a detailed tutorial is a pretty important aspect especially when it comes to strategic games, may it be new players of the genre or the seasoned ones. Every game of the genre has something that is differently executed than the others, and learning the ropes easily depends on this.

    [*][b]Atmospheric Soundtracks[/b] - The soundtracks made for this game really gets the feel and presence of going into a war, which adds to a wholesome game experience and more importantly, the tracks aren't the annoying type that makes you mute them after hearing it repeatedly.

    [*][b]Great Value[/b] - Presenting a price of three (3) games for one is a very enticing offer, and even more if the games deliver to what they offer as advertised. Seeing through the game, it seems that there are more contents to come and it'll definitely be a plus for the game.

[/list] 

[h1][u][b]The Cons[/b][/u][/h1]

[list]

    [*][b]Similar Gameplay[/b] - Though there might be differences in terms of period setting and some gameplay mechanics that differentiates each of the three, there isn't really anything that makes them standout from one or the other as a whole.

    [*][b]Crude Interface[/b] - A thing that really bothers me in every game is when it doesn't have a clean interface to deliver. The font style used for each of the game are somewhat hard to read and is confusing to the eye at the very least.

[/list] 


[h1][u][b]The Verdict[/b][/u][/h1]

In terms of overall features, this game goes about what a standard strategic game offers. However, it is good to note that it'll be still updated with more content in the near future and is atleast worth the try to get.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991140811', 'num_games_owned': 5786, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1461415857}
review:
[b]Strategy & Tactics: Wargame Collection is a collection of three turn based combat war games including two campaigns and a massive sandbox mode.[/b]

Looking at the screenshots Strategy & Tactics looked a little complicated at first and I wasn't sure if it was something I'd love but I gave it a try and I have no regrets. The game is actually easy to learn and the tutorial is very in depth and talks you through everything as you play so you can properly understand what you need to know.
There are three separate parts to Strategy & Tactics: World War II, World War II Sandbox and Medieval Wars. World War II has a campaign mode where you battle your way across Europe via multiple missions. Additionally you can play multiplayer skirmishes against the computer or hotseat with a friend with rules which you set yourself. There are also various scenarios for you to try, each with different objectives, map sizes and bots so there is plenty of variation. World War II sandbox mode seems to be the same as World War II skirmishes but on a much grander scale. The whole world participates in one large battle where you can choose your country and whether or not you want to play with alliances. You can then set your objective and start playing. I've actually found this mode to be very intense and exciting rather than the smaller scale battles. In the Medieval Wars you'll take part in the Excalibur campaign where you defend, defeat, and reconquer you way through The War of The Roses. The gameplay is almost identical to World War 2 with the exception of names on areas of the map being different, having different units, different music and a nicer looking in- game interface (though this is just my preference).

In the campaign modes you'll start with a tutorial which will explain all about units and movements, attacking and supporting, defending, unit health and objectives. I've not found anything important whilst playing that wasn't explained. Once completing the tutorial you'll be faced with your first mission. Each mission has objectives, optional objectives, defeat conditions and the how many turns you can take to get the gold or silver medals for the said mission. You must use your units to secure victory by conquering key points on the map or clearing out enemy soldiers. Some missions have different ways to win and some have just one. [b]Strategy & Tactics is a very combat based game.[/b] There is little to no diplomacy in the game and it centres around military victory. You'll start with some units, which vary from ground soldiers, to air support to boats and armoured cars (WWII), and a small amount of territory. Some pieces of territory grant resources whilst you own them and those resources are used to call in reinforcements. These reinforcements can be chosen and dropped at any of the key locations you hold and are very pivotal to winning a game. Though there aren't masses of unit types, what you have gets the job done and stops it from being overcomplicated. As you play through missions you'll earn 'Research points' which can be spent upgrading either your military or science research which in turn will improve things like your soldiers strength or health adding some nice progression and an added incentive to complete the missions within the allotted turns. 

The sandbox mode is a lot more intense choosing to focus on large battle. This time instead of playing on small areas of the map the whole map is opened and every country is involved and starts with multiple units and a section of owned territory. You can choose to have alliances turned on for everyone, off for everyone or off for just the player so you can experience battle three different ways. You can also select one of many different end objectives which vary depending on which country you so it doesn't feel repetitive. There are tons and tons of different scenarios you can set up for yourself by combining these different variables. I would recommend playing some of the campaign modes first so you aren't completely overwhelmed but there is still a tutorial here for those who want to dive right in. 

The graphics and music themselves are very reminiscent of older games and although this doesn't bother me some people might be looking for something a little more refined. The in-game interface is nicer in the Medieval Wars game mode in my opinion at it just looks a little more modern but there isn't much difference. 
I should also mention though having a good amount of campaign/scenarios the developers are planning to add more so the current content will actually increase.

Things that could have been improved are: I think there needs to be a button to move to you unit that still have moves. This isn't an issue early on but as you play more and more and the maps get larger you have to do a lot of looking around to make sure you haven't missed something. It is most prominent in the Sandbox mode where there is a lot going on at once. It'd also be nice for difficulty settings as right now the bots just have one difficulty and it can get pretty challenging, especially if you've not played something like this before. I think steam achievements would be a great addition to the game as there are many different scenarios and campaigns to choose from, it'd be nice to be able to track your progress like that. Lastly I can find no way to move into allied territory in sandbox mode. It may be me doing something wrong but I tried everything. I was playing as Great Britain and ended up trapped on the island because France was an ally and I couldn't move into anywhere they owned. 

[b]Overall I think Strategy & Tactics is an awesome combat TBS with plenty of content and very fun gameplay. I've already sunk 3 hours into the sandbox part alone. $10 is a great price for what you get and I think any casual turn based strategy fan should grab it, especially on sale.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198015084066', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1527479204}
review:
First (after) words: this is NOT a game of diplomacy. I don't know if they plan to update and add it, but there's little to no diplomacy whatsoever. The AI does diplomacy sometimes (Finland announces it has joined the Communist Bloc! O_o), but you can't. If you play Sandbox with the pre-set alliance disabled (neutral, Allied, Axis), everyone fights everyone. It's still really fun, but I thought I would warn you. This is a combat game, not a diplomacy game!

There isn't any other reviews yet, as far as I can see, so I thought I'd write a super-quick 10 minutes first impression on launch, so you might be spared the hassle to refund if you don't like it.

First things; graphics and sound is very dated. The game does not look pretty in the least. There also is no sound slider, but with the rather sad quality of the audio you might as well mute it.

Now for gameplay. I haven't played enough to find the real depth or tactics yet, of course, but I can say that altough the UI is a bit clunky, the game works well. It seems to be the straightforward WW2 sandbox game I've always wanted. Hearts of Iron is too complex and slow for me, while Risk has too much luck. This is a middlepoint between the two extremes, more towards RISK but without any stupid dice.

Would I recommend it as of now? Yes, yes I would. It's clunky, and looks bad, but you probably already saw that from the pictures. There's a specific type of gamer that would enjoy this, and if you are already looking at the reviews, you probably are that person. 

((45 Minutes later edit)) - the AI is pleasingly competent, and I feel there's more than enough depth and content already to justify the price. If you are looking for a milsim game, this is not it. If you want to play Risk with no luck against AI that's surprisingly skilled, this is it.
